program_name: MISO Demand Response Resources (DRR) - Energy Market - Missouri
description: Demand Response Resources (DRR) Type I and Type II are MISO's energy market demand response programs that allow resources to participate economically in day-ahead and real-time energy markets. Unlike LMRs which are capacity resources, DRRs are dispatched based on economic signals when locational marginal prices exceed the Net Benefit Price Threshold (NBPT). DRR Type I resources cannot follow dispatch instructions (e.g., utility interruptible load programs), while DRR Type II resources can receive and follow MISO operator instructions (e.g., behind-the-meter generation). DRRs cleared in the Planning Resource Auction have a must-offer obligation in the day-ahead energy market.

service_territories: MISO Midwest Region - Eastern Missouri only

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Minimum 1 MW (1,000 kW) load reduction capability required for DRR participation in MISO energy markets. Can be aggregated to meet minimum.

capacity_rate.notes: DRRs do not receive capacity payments unless also registered as LMRs separately. DRRs have no must-offer requirement if not participating in capacity market.

performance_rate.notes: DRRs are paid the Locational Marginal Price (LMP) for demand reduction IF the LMP exceeds the Net Benefit Price Threshold (NBPT). NBPT has ranged from $28 to $52/MWh over the past year. MISO is proposing to set NBPT as minimum offer floor, preventing DRRs from bidding below NBPT.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: DRRs that fail to respond to spinning reserve deployment instructions face small penalties. Independent Market Monitor found that out of 213 spinning reserve deployments in 2023-24, more than 40% of DRR Type I resources did not perform adequately. MISO is proposing enhanced penalties for non-performance.

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: None required for energy-only participation. If cleared in PRA for capacity, must offer into day-ahead market.
nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: Market Participants submit DRR Energy offers into Day-Ahead Market and/or Real-Time Market. MISO is proposing minimum offer floor at NBPT ($28-52/MWh) to prevent below-cost bidding. DRRs cleared for capacity have must-offer obligation in day-ahead market.

special_attributes: DRR Type I cannot follow dispatch instructions - block-based commitments only
DRR Type II can follow dispatch instructions and receive MISO operator instructions
Only DRR Type II eligible for Ramp Capability Product
DRR Type I and Type II eligible for Spinning Reserve (up to 40% of spin requirement)
DRRs can provide either Energy or Contingency Reserve but not both simultaneously (Type I restriction)
Net Benefit Price Threshold (NBPT) determines payment eligibility
As of 2023: only 521 MW registered as DRR Type I and 79 MW as DRR Type II

program_evolution.change_description: MISO proposed setting NBPT as minimum offer floor for DRR energy offers in day-ahead and real-time markets to prevent market gaming
Independent Market Monitor identified 40%+ non-performance rate for DRR Type I in spinning reserve deployments

data_sources.source_name: MISO BPM-026 Demand Response Business Practices Manual
MISO MSC - Demand Response Participating as Supply Resource

data_sources.url: https://cdn.misoenergy.org/MSC Demand Response Participating as a Supply Resource in MISO Markets (MSC-2024-6) (20240822)_WPPI648323.pdf

data_sources.source_name: Renewable Energy World - MISO DR Program Changes

integration_metadata.notes: BATTERY SUITABILITY ASSESSMENT: DRR program has LIMITED SUITABILITY for battery energy storage systems due to the following factors: (1) 1 MW minimum threshold is accessible for utility-scale batteries, (2) DRR Type II allows following dispatch instructions which suits battery operational capabilities, (3) Energy-only payments based on LMP when LMP > NBPT ($28-52/MWh) provides economic dispatch opportunities, (4) Can participate in Spinning Reserve market for additional revenue, (5) 5-minute dispatch granularity aligns with battery response capabilities. HOWEVER, MAJOR LIMITATIONS EXIST: (1) Payment only when LMP exceeds NBPT means many hours may have zero revenue, (2) NBPT range of $28-52/MWh is relatively low compared to battery operational costs including degradation, (3) 40%+ non-performance penalty concerns indicate regulatory scrutiny on DR resources, (4) Low participation (only 79 MW registered as DRR Type II) suggests limited market attractiveness, (5) Cannot provide Energy and Contingency Reserve simultaneously (Type I restriction). RECOMMENDATION: Batteries should evaluate Electric Storage Resource (ESR) model instead, which provides full energy market participation without NBPT limitations and allows participation in all ancillary service markets. DRR model better suited for traditional load curtailment or behind-the-meter diesel generation rather than batteries. If pursuing DRR, must register as Type II to follow dispatch instructions.
